We hurried to set up before it got too late the retrieved water from the low creek and cooked our dinner. Sidewinder and I had our dehydrated meal I made.  It wasn’t too bad. It consisted of dried black beans, deer hamburger, corn,rice and taco seasoning. I need to make more for our big hike coming up. I also packed in a cupcake for Silverfox for her birthday.  She was surprised even though it was in pretty rough shape.  We had one opportunity to tell hikers about our fundraising hike we have coming up in 3 weeks.  Now we are all comfy in our hammocks and Silverfox in her new tent. Now we wait for the rain.  Night.

I woke up earl today after a restless sleep. I just don’t get a sound sleep.  I had my coffee as I waited for the other 2 to get up.  Chatted with a few of the hikers. Eventually sidewinder and Silverfox got moving and we hit the trail by 9:30.  Today’s hike was a lot of rock scrambling that just seem to never end and we were out in the open in the heat of the day at a good bit. Although it was fun and challenging it was rather tiring after a while. We did enjoy the latter although we were going Sobo we had to go down the ladder. That wasn’t too bad. We saw quite a few hikers again today. And then took state line trail down to the marina where we parked. We met up with friends and  had drinks and something to eat.   It was Her birthday.   She also shuttled us back to the car so Silverfox could head out.  We actually hiked more than a 7.9 miles because we went to Stateline Trail and down the trail but I didn’t count that since I previously counted that middle section before

My brother and his girls picked my daughter and i up After I got done work and we made the four a half hour trek down to Lexington Virginia where we had a hotel room for the night. He so graciously offered to drive us down  to start our hike. It was really nice to have my brother and his girls with us this year. We are doing a fundraiser hike this year. We are helping Dr. Margie Klapper from  Fox Chase hospital so she can continue her research for never smoker lung cancer. My brothers wife Janet passed away from a form of never smokerr lung cancer.  Called ALK. 


My brother and his girls drove us to the trail head at Hog Camp Gap and we started south bound or SOBO as it is called.  They day went pretty well and we made fast miles in the morning.  By 12:30 we had 8 miles in.  We stopped for lunch at a Brown Mountain creek shelter.  It is alway nice to rest at a shelter because they usually have a picnic table and maybe a privy and  somewhere just to rest for a while.  We usually like to take her shoes off during this time. We continued on while down 3 mile decent. Although going down is it always that hard we know that that usually means you’re going to have to go back up. We did see one dear but that was about all. We finally got to where we were going to stop for the day which was like 12.7 miles. 
We were feeling good so we decided to push on.  If  we didn’t then  tomorrow we were going to have two huge climbs. We also have plans for more miles tomorrow so this would help bring that down. The mountain we had to conquer was a 1200 feet elevation change in 2 miles.  It was rough.  I had to finally sit down and rest.  But we were almost at the top where we would set up camp. By this time we had done 15 miles.   We changed out of our sweat drenched clothes, set up our hammocks an cooked dinner.  Mine consisted of Alfredo noodles with tuna. It was very good. Then finally we had to hang our food so the bears don’t get it.  Well how do you do that when the trees are so tall with no branches that we can get to. We did the best we could.  It is 6:30 and we are just chilling in our hammocks. It’s too early to go to sleep.  But not much else to do.  Till tomorrow.

I slept pretty well at our campsite.  It was very breezy for a summer night. I heard something howling in the distance and hoped that it stayed where it was.  I woke up pretty early and had my coffee and breakfast in the morning breeze.  My breakfast consisted of a mixture of carnation infant breakfast, protein powder, hot choc, and oatmeal. We started our hike a little before 9. Over all it wasn’t a bad day. We had a small down hill then basically a 4 mile climb.  Although it want too bad because it went on a slow incline and kinda wrapped back and forth up the mountain until we got to the top where the switchbacks started.  Halfway up the hill we stopped at Punchbowl shelter to lol for a NOBO guidebook he left behind. No luck. But it gave us something to do. We finally had a nice view at PunchBowl overlook. It really was beautiful. We finally created the mountain and were headed for the 5 mile down hill.  I was tough.  We were sweating like crazy.  I know down hill and tough.  It just went on and on.  Our feet and knees were killing us. We finally walked along the creek for quite some time but at this point I just wanted to be done. Finally we came out of the woods and met our shuttle driver from Stanimals hostel. The first thing we did was get on the WiFi.  We have had bad cell service the past 2 days. We then showered did laundry and got our supplies.  We noticed our friend was at the free shelter for hikes in Glasgow.  We decided to go find her.  When we walked in and she saw us she came running for hugs. It was so much fun catching up with her we went and had dinner together and we’re reminiscing about trail days.   It was sad to say good bye but we told her we would see her in Pennsylvania. It was time to get back to the hostel and get ready for tomorrow.  We have a big day ahead of us.

Our day started early with Lee our shuttle driver from Stanimals in Glasgow picking us up at 7.  I was up early and had coffee and breakfast all ready. We took a 45 min drive to Cornelius Creek Shelter which is .2 miles off the Blue Ridge Parkway.  We headed into the woods hoping we were going in the right direction.   Thankfully we were. We came to the shelter that was full of thru hikers and also Boy Scouts. We said hello and continued on. We had a small climb and was hoping it was the big one.  Of course not.  We then had our 1000 foot climb. It was work but it wasn’t terrible.   We were at Apple Orchard meadow.  It was like a mountain bald.  There was a weather tower at the top.  It looked like the Epcot ball. As we started coming down the other side, bam, there was the Guillotine.   It was much bigger in person than i have seen in pictures.  It was a change of pace and also gave us something to make our hike not seem so dull. We finally came to Thunder hill shelter where we met up with 5 they hikers. Through out the day we were leap frogging with them.  It also made the day interesting. We came to Thunder ridge overlook. It was just beautiful.  We hiked on for quite a while going down hill gradually.  Almost 1400 feet.  It just kept going and going.  At the bottom we all had lunch and continued on.  We had one more climb.  At this point it was very hot and the air was very stale. It was a 700 foot climb but it was steeper.  We were exhausted by this time. After regrouping  we pushed on. We had another 8 miles of down hill to go.  We could hear rumbling in the distance and hoped we could beat the rain.  WRONG! 6 miles left and the flood gates opened up.  We were running down the mountain as quickly and safely as we could until our knees couldn’t take it anymore.   Finally the rain slowed down.  At this point we were drenched.  6 miles down hill is very tough.  It is not physically exhausting but it is hard on the body. We finally got to the shelter and just sat for a few minutes to give our body time to rest. We had 2 more easy miles left until we got to foot bridge to cross the James River.  By this time the sun was out and it was beautiful.  We were finally done.  We hiked 20.1 miles today. Thankfully we slackpacked because we were going back to Stanimals tonight. The only problem is, we were an hour early for our shuttle.  We sat with our new they hiker friends and we put our thumbs out trying to get a hitch. It took a while but finally a truck stopped and took us all.  It was very nice.  We got to town as our shuttle driver was headed out to get us.  I finally had cell service and could call him and he turned around and picked us up at the store to go back to the hostel.  Shwew.  It was a long day.

Got up early to get ready for a shuttle that was coming at 7 o’clock. We took the hour drive up to camellias Creek shelter and this time we’re going southbound. Was getting carsick on the way up because we were on all these winding  roads and the Blue Ridge Parkway. It was a relief to get back out on the trail in the fresh air. This morning there’s a slight breeze which is so refreshing. We’re trying to make some miles today because rain is coming this afternoon again if we can push for 12 we can make. It to a shelter.  The only problem is there is no water there. 
We started off our hike with 6/10 mile climb going south. Nothing like waking up the lungs first thing in the morning.   It was quite an exhausting day.  Lots of climbs today and it was hot and humid on the mountain tops.  I was just not into hiking today.  I think because I was dreading the rain.  If we get caught in it today then we are wet for days.  We do not get anywhere near a town till Thursday. We pressed on.  We finally got to a road crossing with a huge stream. We sat and had lunch and wadded in the water.  It was so refreshing. After one exhausting climb we had to take a break at the top.   Not for long because we heard rumbling.  We kicked it in high gear.  We were 1 mile until the shelter.  Today my feet were bothering me.  I think the down hill is killing my heels and the uphill is bothering my big toe joint.  I manage with some duct tape on the skin to stop the rubbing. We made it to the shelter and actually had cell phone service and looked at the weather.  The rain pushed off until 5:30.  We decide to get 4 more miles in so we could stay on our schedule. One more big climb.  The only good thing about this one is that Sidewinder could pick blueberries as we climbed the mountain. We only saw one deer today and it wasn’t scared of us at all.  We also saw a few Lizards and snails.  We finally made it to Bearwallow gap. We also beat the rain.  We hurried and got water and set up our hammocks because the rain was coming.  We just finished and started cooking when the rain started. We huddled in our hammocks and ate dinner.  I tried to hang our food so the bears don’t get it. But once again they are all tall trees.  Maybe a bear canister is needed.  Well it’s quite early but not much to do since it is raining and no cell service.  So I guess I will try to go to sleep.  7 pm.  That’s a first for me

Wow. I woke up at 6am. I slept 10.5 hours. Except for the Whip poor will that was singing at midnight and 5 am I slept great. Our day started off with a climb out of bearwallow gap.     After that we came to a view at Peaks of otter over look.  We were in the clouds.   It was such a view.  The trail continued on for many miles with views and overlooks.  We saw a small snake and some newts.  Over all the trail was pretty easy. We passed 2 shelters today.  The first we stopped for water. The second we decided to stop and eat and to decide if we should stay there or continue.   The storms were brewing so it was a calculated risk. We want to stay on target and we could get to another shelter so we pushed on.  The only thing it meant instead of the easy day it turned into a hard day.  We had a step 1000 foot climb followed by a steep 500 foot climb. As we started the first one the storm kicked in.  At first the cold rain was refreshing but in rained harder and we decided to get our rain gear out.  I am glad we did I was getting cold.  Eventually it diminished and the sun peeked out as we did our last climb to the shelter.  Well what do you know but there was a Boy Scout group there.  Great.  No really they were well behaved and quiet very early.  Today my feet are getting sore. I feel like a blister is starting on my heel.  I am trying to use duct tape on my heel to give it slip.  I think all the down hills are doing it. Today

I woke up early to the Boy Scouts getting packed up very quietly.  I had my coffee and breakfast with the other thru hikers. It was nice to compare stories and to see where everyone was from. Then one of the hiker food bags was stuck in the trees.  The knot he used was so tight on the PCT hang that we couldn’t release it. Finally after 2 of us helping he got it down.   Sidewinder and I packed up our stuff and hit the  trail because today is the day we were meeting our friends Silver fox at the Troutville exit. The hike was mostly downhill but it was very wet from the rain the day before and kind of walking on the side of the mountain going down so we had to be very careful not to slip or fall.  It took us a while to get down the mountain. It was a nice relief to see our friend waiting at the trail for us. She took us back to the hotel where we were able to get cleaned up a little bit.  We ran to McDonald’s before we parked her car at the hotel. We now needed to walk the mile to the trail head. As we started walking we saw a truck leaving Cracker Barrel and we politely asked for a hitch to the trail head. He was more than willing to give us a ride.  Today’s hike was pretty strenuous and exhausting for all of us. We continued on because we wanted to get to tinkers cliffs to see the sunset. At one point we all needed to pee.   Of course just when I squat a male hiker comes by.  We could walk for miles without seeing a hiker but of course as soon as I need to pee, there he is. I scrambled to get my shorts up as we all had a good laugh.  Sometimes we need this to change the dulldrum of the strenuous hike.  Yes and even sometimes boring.  As we hiked on there was a Shelter 2 miles before Tinkers cliffs. We stopped there for water. It was supposed to rain today pretty heavily but thankfully it never did.  So we continued the hard climb up the cliffs. The view was breathtaking and well worth the climb.  Shortly after the sunset we set up camp and quickly cooked before it got dark. It is now 10:30 and we are all settled in.  I hope I sleep it is quiet windy.

Well we took a walk on the wild side and decided to stealth camp on Tinkers Cliffs. Hikes are not supposed to camp up there in the state park. Last night we got there right at sunset.  It was beautiful.  It was kinda late to push on so we set up camp there. We had hiked enough.  So this morning I had set my alarm set for 5:30 to catch the sunrise. Well the night did not go as planned. The winds kicked in so bad that it was howling all night.  My hammock was rocking back and forth and I was cold from the wind blowing so much. Bad idea to sleep up there. The even worse I was hoping to see a beautiful sunrise. I sat out on the cliffs wrapped in my underquilt watching for the sun to come up.  O sun to be seen.  Even worse it looked like storm clouds rolling in. I did get a few pics of clouds etc but no sunrise. So we started packing up with hopes to be on the trail at 8am and also hoping not to get caught camping at the cliffs. As we were gathering g our stuff 5 deer wandered In really close to us.  That was pretty neat. Then we look out at the cliffs and there is a rainbow. It was beautiful.  A once in a lifetime moment.   We finally hit the trail and hiked swims tough miles until we got to McAfee knob.  The last half mile was exhausting. We got to the top and took a few pictures and along cake the trail maintainer. After talking to him we found out that the knob was just up a bit more.  Oh my gosh it was huge. I have visually dreamed of this place and we were finally here. We took our turns getting pictures along with the rest of the crowd.  I did find it rude that2 women sat in the background where they were clearly in everyone’s pictures. They were oblivious. Oh well. After the knob we still had alit of hiking to do.  Again some hard climbs for all of us. We met up with Patriot68 a 71 year old southbounder. We couldn’t even keep up with him. We finally came out to the road where 4 Pines hostel was.  Luckily a women was dropping off hikers and gave us a ride.  Our 3rd hitch this hike. We literally dropped our gear and they shuttled us to an all you can eat dinner buffet called Homeplace.  It was as really good. Then finally got back and Silverfox showered while I started laundry. There is no dryer so we have all our clothes hanging on our bunks to dry. There is 1 shower for about 15 hikers.  So Sidewinder had to wait a while.  10 pm was lights out.   So now I lay in my top bunk Sidewinder beside me and silverfox below her.  Meanwhile 2 hikers are snoring away.  Guess there won’t be much sleep tonight either.

We decided to sleep in and take a slower start this morning. Sidewinder and Silver Fox wanted to sleep. With the intense day of Dragons tooth ahead of us we planned on a shorter day.  We made friends with Patriot68(a 71 year old gentleman), Fox Feet and Fairweather yesterday. We all decided to slackpack Dragons tooth. We split the $20 shuttle fee to drive us to our starting point.  Patriot68 lead the way as Sidewinder and I followed the others following behind us. Overall the climb was not too bad.  We had a lot of switchbacks which made it a pretty easy climb. As we neared the top we would climb some pretty good rock sections.  Each time we would get to the top we thought we were there. But then it flattened out until we got to another rock section.  By this time 3 of us lead and the other 3 were behind just a bit.  When we would get to a hard section or a section where they may miss a turn we would wait for them. Eventually I got to a blue blaze for Dragons tooth. I waited for the others to catch up and we finally arrived at this huge mass of rocks.  You didn’t have to climb to the top but since we got this far we had to try. I got almost to the top.  I was afraid if I went any further I would not be able to get back down.  We sat and had lunch then took the long rock scramble down the trail.  It was quite precarious at some spots.  Just when we thought we were off the rocks we came to another rock section. We joked this was the dragons tail.  Then more rocks.  By now my knees are aching from all the down hill.  We eventually hit a bunch of switchbacks leading us to the road.  We had a 1/4 mile walk to the hostel.  I was so glad to be gone this day.  It was amazing but I think it also was one of the toughest days.  Sidewinder held up well on the down hills especially with the knee issue she is having. We all ordered pizza and just chilled out at the hostel. We made some great friends today with the other SOBO’s. We officially completed the Virginia triple crown. This has been something I have been looking forward to.

Today we started our day by catching our shuttle at 7 AM along with our other Sobo friends.  We took the long winding road up to the trail head. By this time three of us were ready to puke. What a way to start our 4 mile climb to the top of the Audi Murphy memorial. Although the climb was not one of the worst we had this section it was very long but luckily it was not the steepest. At this point we all had our trail legs and we’re doing really well. Patriot68 was waiting at the top for us and we all sat down and had a snack. Eventually Foxfeet and Fairweather caught up to us. They seem to like to take a slower pace than we do.  At this point we had the long downhill to get to the road where our friend Dee would be picking us up. We picked this location because it was the only road crossing that was convenient for all of us. The hike became fun because all we did was pick blueberries for Sidewinder to eat.  I also think we were a little bit perkier knowing that today was our last day and the torture was over. We have all taken a toll on our bodies from this hike. Sidewinder thinks she has a torn meniscus, I have two blisters and my knees are aching, and Silver fox’s hip started acting up today. We got down to the bottom of the trail 15 minutes earlier than we thought. As we waited for her friend Dee the time seemed to take by which we thought was a little odd because she’s always a little early. Upon trying to call her and text her her phone went right to voicemail. This was a little concerning for us so we tried to get a hold of her family. Now all we’re thinking is how the heck are we going to get out of here with no ride and where the heck is Dee. I stop the car coming down the road to see if they saw her. No luck. Just then Sidewinder was able to get through to Dee and  she had trouble finding the exact location. She needed to find cell phone service but she was around the corner from us. We now could go for lunch and get Silver Fox back to her car and drive the 5.5 hours home. We completed 126.2 miles in 9 days. We had to cut our hike 2 days short for an appointment tomorrow.  We would like to thank our 2 shuttle drivers  and all her sponsors who helped us raise $4415 for Margie Clappers Lab to research Never Smoker Lung Cancer.  


This hike is Dedicated to Janet Plasha 4-30-19

I left the house at 5:00 am to meet Chuck and Todd and we caravanned to our started with a 2 1/2 hour drive to New York where we left our car at S. Mountain Pass Rd. I had arranged a shuttle from a great friend name Donna who lives in that area and shuttled us to our starting point at Elk Pen gap. Our plan was to hike 12.7 miles. and try and catch up to our friends silver fox and her son who had started the day before but we’re doing lower miles, and we would end at the same location this evening. Our Day quickly started with a nice climb out of the gap along with some rock sections. Eventually we came to a mountaintop that was pretty flat and enjoyable and before we knew it Bam we were at the lemon squeezer. I wasn’t quite sure what to expect but it was much more narrow than I anticipated. I watch my friend Todd try to get through with this pack on and there was no way he was getting through. My pack was a bit smaller so I decided to give it a shot and had no problem although it was interesting trying to finagle through. Chuck managed to get through and then Todd handed his pack up to us and would led his way through as well.  I’ve never heard that there’s a rock climb right after the lemon squeezer but there it was. We were trying to decide if we should take the easy trail around or go up over the scramble. My thought was we had to at least try it. So off I went up over the rock scramble carefully placing my feet and hands and had no problem. The guys with their heavier packs handed their packs up and then made their way up through.  I sure am glad we tried it. We continued on to the fingerboard Shelter. Where we took a little break. Unfortunately there was no water at the shelter. But as we carried on we soon came to the water towers where there was a nice stash of water.   We continued hiking and trying to catch up with our friend. Later we realized we totally missed Tiorati circle where we could’ve got snacks and drinks. We then found a nice flat rock and sat and had her lunch. Chuck and I both packed tortillas with tuna and some snacks. Todd only had one of the goo electrolyte packets. When I asked him he said he wasn’t hungry. We hiked on and eventually got to the William Brien shelter where we found silver fox and her son getting ready to head out to hike.  Again no water at the shelter. Water has been very scarce on this section most of the creeks being dry. From there we hiked together. Eventually we passed over Palisades Parkway which we have always heard horror stories of the high traffic. Luckily it was a Saturday for us and although the traffic was heavy it was no problem to cross. We eventually carried on and got to a creek which was flowing well and all took on extra water because the next shelter also had no water.  We had one more big climb which was tough. Part way through Todd was having difficulty and I realized that he was not drinking or eating enough to fuel his body. We got a power bar and some electrolytes in him and continues. Later he told what a difference they made.  People don’t realize ho many calorie they are burning on a hike like this.  We took the half mile side trail to West Mountain Shelter which overlooked the Hudson River and New York  City.   I set up my hammock and sat on the rock overlooking the River. Th shelter was quite full today. We enjoyed the sunset and city skyline.

I woke up early to the sunlight shining in my hammock. I had a restless sleep again. I grabbed my bear bag and sat on the rock ledge overlooking the city and the Hudson. I made my coffee and sat and relaxed by myself. When i finished we all packed up and hit the trail. We had 9.2 miles to complete our hike. We had a pretty nice part of the trail until we hit our first climb. It was a pretty tough one. The trail leveled off and we made it to Bear Mountain.Some of us climbed the tower, and enjoyed the view.  We couldn’t wait to hit up the vending machines. I downed 2 cokes and a Pringle’s. That was the first time i ever saw a Pringle’s vending machine. We then took the long long trail down the stairs. Wow lots of trail maintenance on those steps. It drops you into Bear Mountain Rec center. Wow talk about lots of people. It was a little awkward walking thru all the people. A few people asked us about our hike. We then walked thru the Zoo. That also was fun but interesting as well. Just odd being part of the trail. From there we crossed the Bear Mountain bridge and headed into the woods, and up the mountain which seemed like forever. We all could not wait till we were at the top. It never seemed to end, People kept saying you are almost there. We had another 2 mile’s which breezed by and soon enough we were at our car. Now the 2.5 hour ride home

Sidewinder and I drove up to Fishkill NY where we met up with Silverfox.  We Chile’s our so we could hike in the morning.
       The day started out with breakfast at the hotel. Which wasn’t too bad.  We then drove to the trail head where we left our car and met our surprise shuttle driver Silverfox lined up. Turns out it was our friend Donna who lives near here.  She drove us North and we started our hike south.  Overall we had a really good hike. The first thing we started on was the plank boards which had a layer of frost and almost bit the dust first thing. We quickly learned that everything was slippery because there was just a slight frost. Eventually that frost turn to wetness and just made everything slippery. I fell one time because it was slick. But overall it was a good day. I stopped at the shelter to grab lunch   As we continue taking we got to an area where there were a bunch of blow downs and we heard that there was a possible tornado that had come through there at one time. Our day ended with 12 miles  I felt pretty good considering I hadn’t hiked  in a while. We went back to the hotel and grabbed hot coffee which is just what we needed after such a cold day.  We ended the day meeting up with two of our friends from Hike for Mental Health.  We had an amazing dinner and drinks

We started off the day with breakfast at the hotel.  We had to drop off one car at Taconic State Pkway then drive to Dennytown road where we started. The hike today was much better. It Was a crisp cold morning.  So the ground was frozen and much less slippery than the day before.  Overall the hike was not that strenuous with little ups and downs here and there and we quickly warmed up as the day went on and stripped layers off as we went. At one point I was down to a T-shirt which is crazy for a December day. It probably was in the 40s but we worked up enough of a sweat which is not good when it’s so cold so we removed our layers.  Eventually we stopped for lunch and ended up with all her layers back on. This happened through most of the day which is away I call this a bipolar day. We crossed several streams today and walk to practically around the Canopus lake.  It seem like it was never going to end.   The days seem to go pretty quickly ending by 3 o’clock with 11.1 miles. We then had the 3 hour drive home.

We had a late start for our drive to NY to meet our friend Donna who is shuttling us to Kent CT.  We finally met her around 6:30 and hit the trail a little after 7. We had a decision to make.  Do we hike .3 miles and camp at the shelter or hike on to the next campsite which was on 3 miles. The next day was going to be a lot of rain.  In the end. We decided to stay at shelter instead of hiking at night and setting up. As we got to the shelter we ran into 3 hikers who I met in Pennsylvania when I was hiking.  We even talked about maybe seeing each other when we hit CT. It was nice catching up with them.

I actually slept pretty good last night. There was a roaring stream that lulled me to sleep. I woke up at 4 am to it raining. Just great. Eventually I got up around 6:30 and it was barely raining.  The other hikers had been up and eating and packing up. I made my coffee and chatted with them. If it’s one thing I love, it’s my coffee in the morning.  Sidewinder got up and we said good bye to the guys.  Since it wasn’t raining we packed up and started hiking.  In no time it started raining.  It was slightly refreshing because it was warm and sticky out. So we just hiked in the rain. As we were hiking we started seeing all these salamanders.   So we started counting them.  In the first mile we saw 100 salamanders.  For the whole day we saw 200.  We had a lot of slab rocks we were hiking across. It was treacherous and we had to be careful.  Rocks, moss and wet don’t mix. We finally made it to 10 mile shelter and sat and ate out lunch.  In no time it started raining.  Then pouring.  We got cold fast so we started pulling out our gear.  We took a nap as we were all snuggled in our quilts. In the end we sat for 3 hours until the rain stopped.  Now we had 4 more miles to go. We had a mile climb right off the bat.  It wasn’t as bad as we expected.  We meandered the rest of the trail and came to a foot bridge that was out of service. But we heard you could cross anyway.  So we did carefully. It was better than road walking a mile.  Made it to the shelter cooked, ate and set up by 8:00. As I am writing my journal we hear an owl going hoot hoot, hoot.

I woke up at 5 AM in the morning a little chilly from the morning air. I still had a jacket  I could  put on but as long as I stayed under my underquilt I was fine. I finally woke at 6 am from the sun shining.  Thank goodness   I made my coffee and read the log book.  It was fun to see names of previous people I shuttled.   Since sidewinder was still sleeping I decided to clean up the shelter. There was ramen all over and lots of trash.  I swept all the trash together and swept the floor.  I didn’t want to touch the trash because of the Covid virus. 
We parked up and started our Hike. It was easy day with not too much elevation changes.  We had woods, swamps, plank boards,cow pastures and even a boardwalk section.  Then The fueling part started. We had 2 climbs the second one was a struggle. I wish I was a little younger doing these climbs.  But we did it.  We then walked along Nuclear lake which was pretty. Finally arriving at our car.  Then we were going to meet our friend Donna at South Mountain pass road to be shuttled to another section to hike. She informed us that the parking was closed.  What to do, what to do. So we flipped our hike and parked at the bigger lot.  We stopped for pizza with Donna before she dropped us off for our next leg of your hike.  Again I am snug in my hammock listening to an owl hoot. Till next time

I woke up this morning to the sound of rain again. I looked at the radar and it show no rain. The weather channel show 5%. Just our luck. So I went back to sleep for a little longer than normal. Eventually got up and got our food that we hung so the bear couldn’t get it. Then set my hammock tarp up into porch mode. That way I could cook my food and make my coffee and still stay dry. I was able to just relax drinking my coffee until  it was time to get Sidewinder  moving. We had a little over 12 miles today and we want to get it done because we have a  3 Hour drive home as well. The day started out not too bad. The rain has stopped and the hiking was fairly easy. I did have two pretty good climbs today maybe three but overall they weren’t too bad. We eventually got to the hill top shrine on top of the mountain which was a nice place to sit and take a break. But then we pushed on to try and get our day done.  We saw quite a few day hikers again today and a couple people that were doing some overnights. A lot of people stopped and put their masks on when they got to us because of the Covid.  By the end of the day Sidewinder and I were both Sore. Sidewinders feet were really bad and I was just running out of steam. I think the three days back to back was just getting to me. I finally had our last climb and meander through the top of the mountain and then gentle long downhill until we got to our car. I have to say this hike was the most aromatic hike.  The honeysuckle were in full bloom.  It smelled so good. Yippee we were done 38.2 miles in the books

Our hike started by traveling 4 hours to Massachusetts where we met out shuttle driver/friend Susan.  I previously shuttled her in PA.  She shuttled a us about an hour south to Kent Connecticut where we would start our hike north back to our car. 
         We said goodbye to Susan and headed straight up the hill.  What a way to start.  We paced ourselves and continued on.  As we were hiking something scrambled off the trail.  To our surprise it was a bobcat.   It was staring straight at Sidewinder(Kara).   She froze.    I said take a picture.( she is always in the lead)    I eventually was able to get a video as it just slowly meandered away.  So that was pretty exciting.   We the came to St John’s Ledges. That’s exactly what is was.  This huge rock ledge we had to scramble down.  It was quite technical.  Then we had literally a 5 mile walk along a river.  Although the walk was not bad we were bombarded by gnats and mosquitoes.   There literally was a swarm following us.  We tried to keep a quick pace to get away from them and to make up some time we lost earlier in the day.  Our last part of our hike was another grueling climb.   It was steep and just seemed to never end.  Finally at the bottom we had the owner of Coltsfoot valley farm pick us and other hikers up.  We went back to his farm where we had a bed, shower and a fresh vegetable and pasta dinner and also cheese that he made on the farm.    It was a perfect way to end the day. We were so tired and didn’t expect to get dinner too.  It was a full house with 6 hikers and the host.

Woke up early to enjoy my coffee. The house was quiet while I set up my camp stove. Spirit a man who camped in his tent joined me and we chatted.  We had done the PCT and 3/4 of the way done the AT.  Eventually everyone was ready and we made a quick stop at the market for a coffee for everyone.  We then got dropped off and headed down the side of the mountain where we had to ford across the river.    I chose to take me trail runners off and put my crocks on.  While Sidewinder decided to chance it and go across.  She tiptoed across the rocks even with her coffee in had.  Not me.  I guzzled mine.  Of course after that there was another good climb.  I question my self if I am getting too old for this or what.  Maybe I should have trained more.  
       We passed several hikers the past 2 days.  Some section hikers some southbounders or SOBO’s and we leapfrogged with several hikers going NOBO.  Today was a slightly boring hike with the only interesting thing being  Rogers Ramp.  It was a small narrow passage between rocks that we had to squeeze thru.  The mosquitoes again were terrible.  We stopped at the shelter for a rest and water.  Water is really prevalent in CT. This is helpful so we don’t have to carry so much water.  We also saw lots of tiny toads while hiking today.  About 3 miles from our destination we came to Hang glider view.   As we sat and had a snack we could look out over Lime Rock Speedway. It was neat to see the cars racing from afar.  We had one more climb to do.  The last one always gets me.  But finally we made it to the campsite around 5:30. We set up with 2 other hikers and chatted while we cooked and ate dinner.  They are 2 friends from 8th grade who now are they hiking. I am happy to now be in my hammock relaxing. It’a only 8:30 so I hope not to go to sleep too early or I will be awake at 3am.  Stay tuned

I had the most restless night on the trail. First of all hikers came into our camp in the dark shining their lights all sound and talking loudly.  The finally leave and set up on the hill.  The were up talking loudly till after midnight.   Then I finally fall asleep and wake up again and take a sleeping pill.  I sleep for 3 hours and then am wide awake. Finally get up around 6:30. Enjoyed my coffee peacefully.  We stayed with 4 other hikers who we would leap frog with all day.  We were all excited to get moving this morning because Mountain side cafe was .2 miles off trail. Our limit is .3 for blue blazing.  We moved thru the trail pretty swiftly.   It was mostly down hill.   We also had some road walking and a short side trail to the cafe.  The food was amazing. I had a goat cheese omelet with pesto and tomato.  Side wonder and I also shared streusel French roast with apple compote.  It was amazing.  We left there and hiked along the Housatonic river. It’s a huge river. This river is the most unused river.   For 3 days we have crossed paths with this river and have not seen a single person fishing or kayaking.   We weaved in and out the trail along the river.  Eventually we get to Falls Village. It’s a cute little town.  I would love to go back again some day. We finally come to these rock slabs in the water with a falls behind it where our hiker friends were enjoying the water. At this point we were so hot we jumped right in too.  It was so refreshing. We then continued on our hike. We had to climb Mt Prospect.  It was no picnic..  All my muscles in my legs are so sore already.  It hurt with every step. But slowly we continued.  The mosquitoes were nasty again today. We continued with one more small climb.   Then some crazy switchbacks to get down to the road. The trail followed the road half way into Salisbury. We veered off and walked to Maria’s house.  She is a trail angel who is 92 and has been taking in hikers for 20 years.  She was very happy to see us.  We have a bedroom with 2 twin beds to share.  Maria does not have a washing machine and the laundry was 2 miles away.   So we chose to hand wash our clothes and hang them.  They really needed it. There are 2 other gentleman in there 60’s who are here.  They are thru hiking. Sidewinder and I went to this great pizza shop and got the best Italian meal and a glass of wine. We spent some time just relaxing and  giving our legs a break.  We have a hard day tomorrow.   Today also was the day that I celebrated 800 miles on the trail. I was pretty happy about that.

I woke up early and enjoyed coffee with the rest of the hikers. We talked about our plans for the day. Sidewinder and I were not in a big hurry today because we had plenty of time to do our miles.  It also was going to be a bit cooler today too. We said our good byes to Maria.  She was a neat lady. She really loves having hikers. We started our road walk back to the trail. Then a gentle walk thru the woods and then we began our climb up Lions head mountain.  It is described as a short but difficult climb.  It was an exactly that.  It sure did stretch the sore muscles.  Along this stretch we saw a flock of turkeys and a doe.  We then meandered thru the woods slowly climbing the mountain. We then finally climbed the peak of Bear Mountain. It was rather steep at the top with a huge rock carin that was built in 1885 on top you could see all around.   Bear mountain is the highest peak in Connecticut.  We began our decent down Bear mountain.  It was tough.   Lots of rocks kinda like a rock scramble to go down  and lots of slabs of rocks. It was pretty tricky.  Eventually we climbed down along Sages ravine. We walked all along the flowing stream with deep pools of water.  We took our shoes off and soaked our aching feet. It felt glorious.  But we couldn’t get too comfortable we still had one more mountain to climb.  Mt Race was before us.  In the beginning we had some hard climbing and then it turned into climbing on these rock slabs surrounded by small pine  trees and blueberry bushes.  The blueberries were delicious.  We leapfrogged with several hikers thru  this section.  Eventually we came out to a summit.    It was beautiful.  I thought we were done.  But oh no.  We now had .6 miles of rock ledges to walk on overlooking the mountain.  It wasn’t that hard but you were on the edge and also on an incline. Finally we crested and started down the other side.  We had a mile to go to get to our campsite.  It was a basic campsite but has a bear box and a privy and most importantly water.  We have another huge climb tomorrow.  I also miscalculated because of bad internet calculations and completed my 800 miles on Saturday not yesterday.  As I sit here writing this at 8:30 at night a few more hikers joined us to camp.  Not sure who they are,maybe we will find out tomorrow. There is also the strangest noise in the trees. It must be some type of bird.  Never heard it before.

I had the worst nights sleep ever.  I was so restless all night.  I really don’t know why.  I even took 2 sleeping pills because I wanted to get a good nights sleep. On top of that these dang bird in the trees were making noise all night long. I think I finally slept from 3 to 7 am.  We got a slow start hitting the trail at almost at 10 am.  I think Sidewinder needed to let her feet rest.  We finished down the rest of the mountain only to start up Mt Everett. It is considered a grueling climb compared to the Whites in New Hampshire. It first started with rock scrambles then turned into sheets of rock.   We had to be careful with every step.  One wrong step and we were in for trouble. On top of this some of the rocks were wet from the humidity. This took us much longer as we continued up the mountain.  We finally reach the top with just about no view.   All that work and no view. Well going down was just about the same thing.   Only this time going down felt like we had more ups than down’s. Ironically today I felt the best I have the whole hike.   My muscles weren’t sore and I was less fatigued.   Eventually we made it to the bottom where our car awaited.   We couldn’t wait to get there and change our sweaty stinky clothes.  Well there were 4 people there so we loaded up and started for home. In like true hiker fashion we stopped at the first mini mart and gorged on food and drinks.  It was soooooo good. 


In this section home we completed 49.2 miles, finished another state and completed a total of  800 + miles.
Day hike before Trail days with Charlene
